data.sampled:
Yes, it is possible to translate the above statement into a formal logical system using quantifiers and logic gates. The translation would be as follows:

"For all x, if more people have visited Milan than x, then x must have visited Milan."

This can be expressed in logic programming language like Prolog as:

:- use_module(library(logic)).
% VisitMilan :- person(X), visit(Milan, X).
visitMilan :- 
   morePeopleVisitedMilanThanMe -> true; 
   lessPeopleVisitedMilanThanMe -> false.

In this example, we first define a rule "VisitMilan", which takes a person argument ("X") and checks whether that person has visited Milan (using the built-in predicate "visit/2"). If more people have visited Milan than the current person ("me"), then the result of the rule will be "true". Otherwise, the result will be "false".

We then use the library module "logic" to define two other rules "morePeopleVisitedMilan Than Me" and "lessPeopleVisitedMilan Than Me", which implement the necessary inference steps for translating the sentence into logic form. These rules take an argument ("x") and check whether more people have visited Milan than x ("morePeopleVisitedMilan Than Me"), or less people have visited Milan than x ("lessPeopleVisitedMilan Than Me"). Based on these results, they return either "true" or "false" as the result.

Overall, this translation from natural language to logic form provides us with a way to express the given sentence in a formal manner, allowing us to reason about its truth or falsity based on our knowledge of the world. However, it should be noted that there may be alternative ways to phrase the same information in a more concise or expressive manner, depending on one's specific needs and preferences.

Applying this rule to our situation, we can conclude that if more boys have visited Paris than Mr. X (who we know to be false), then Mr. X must also not have visited Paris. Therefore, we can answer Yes to the question.

Yes, the statement can be translated into a formal logic system as follows:

More men have finished high school than [she has].

This can be expressed using the modus ponens inference rule, which states that if we assume that p is true and q is false, then we can conclude that not-p is also true (i.e., more men have finished high school than she has).

Thus, answering "Y" would be correct, since more men have finished high school than she does. On the other hand, answering "N" would be incorrect, because she in fact has finished high school.
